image.altText: Close up of actress Charlize Theron with short blonde hair

props.synopsis: There is an "unprecedented" level of filming activity across the Canberra region at the moment, with Hollywood stars Eric Bana, Charlize Theron and Taron Egerton all in town.

title.children: Charlize Theron in Canberra amid 'unprecedented' level of screen production activity

image.altText: A concrete building reading "Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory", with Australian, ACT and Aboriginal flag.

props.synopsis: A Canberra doctor accused of sexually assaulting four young women will walk from custody next week, on the condition he is not left alone with any female staff or patients.

title.children: Canberra doctor accused of sexually assaulting four young women gets bail

image.altText: A painting of Rachael Gunn breaking hung on a white gallery wall.

props.synopsis: If there was one notable figure who was going to be parodied in art at this year's Bald Archy, it was always going to be Raygun, whose infamous breakdancing performance at the Paris Olympic Games featured in five entrants' works.

title.children: From Raygun to Dutton, no-one is immune from the satire of the Bald Archy brush

image.altText: A man in a grey suit holds a folder of papers titled 'Budget 2024-25'

props.synopsis: The new ACT treasurer is facing an ambitious task of turning an almost billion-dollar deficit into a small surplus — and he's hoping to improve the books by $850 million in just a matter of months.

title.children: Even a weightlifter might struggle to hoist the ACT out of the economic doldrums

image.altText: elderly man wearing glasses looks at the camera

props.synopsis: ACT Treasurer Chris Steel unveils his first mid-year budget update, forced to reveal the bottom line is in a much worse position than was forecast.

title.children: ACT budget deficit blows out to almost $1 billion

image.altText: Hail on the grass in Weston Creek

props.synopsis: Canberra residents are recovering after a severe thunderstorm made its way across much of the ACT and surrounding regions, knocking out power to around 1,100 households with golf ball sized hailstones and downfalls of 30 millimetres recorded in some suburbs.

title.children: Severe thunderstorm damages roofs, skylights, trees across Canberra

image.altText: A close up of Clive Palmer wearing a blue business shirt in focus with green trees blurred in the background.

props.synopsis: Clive Palmer will take his fight to the in the High Court in Canberra today, as he seeks to re-register his United Australia Party (UAP) ahead of the next federal election.

title.children: Palmer locked in High Court battle to re-register United Australia Party

image.altText: A close-up image of the bud of a cannabis plant.

props.synopsis: A recent study suggests the ACT's cannabis legislation is for the most part working as intended, but shows the majority of cannabis cultivators are engaging in illegal activity in order to grow it.

title.children: Canberra cultivators growing 'mild and modest' cannabis

image.altText: Vache Tovmasyan, Alex Coco, Sean Baker, Mikey Madison and Samantha Quan accept the Best Picture award for "Anora"

props.synopsis: After being postponed twice due to the Los Angeles fires, the 30th Annual Critics Choice awards celebrated the best in film and TV over the last year.

title.children: Anora picks up surprise best picture win at Critics Choice awards — as it happened

image.altText: IMAGE CCA Nicole Kidman landscape

props.synopsis: The biggest names have arrived at the 2025 Critics Choice Awards. See what they wore on the red carpet here.

title.children: What the stars wore on the Critics Choice Awards red carpet

image.altText: Sri Lanka batter Dimuth Karunaratne raises his bat as he walks off in Galle.

props.synopsis: Sri Lanka's Dimuth Karunaratne is dismissed for the last time in Tests as Matthew Kuhnemann removes both openers after Australia takes a 157-run lead into the second innings in Galle. Follow live.

title.children: Kuhnemann ends Sri Lankan great's career as Australia takes early wickets

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Kamindu Mendis chips a catch straight to Usman Khawaja!
Lyon gets wicket number 550 as Chandimal falls!
Karunaratne's Test career comes to an end as Kuhnemann strikes again!

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks at a press conference in brisbane

props.synopsis: The opposition leader says he is "happy to take questions" but won't appear at the National Press Club or offer specifics on his cost-cutting plans.

title.children: An election is nearing and Dutton doesn't seem to have a plan

image.altText: A brown plane seen mid air in a snowy region

props.synopsis: A small commuter plane that crashed in western Alaska on its way to Nome has been found on sea ice, with all 10 people on board confirmed dead.

title.children: Missing Bering Air plane found off Alaska coast, all 10 on board dead

image.altText: A woman facing the ocean holding her arms out with no one else around

props.synopsis: What if being single wasn't a problem to be solved but a state of bliss? For some women, living without their "other half" is the key to being complete.

title.children: 'No situationships, no dating apps, no exes': The women going 'Boysober'

image.altText: Anthony Alabanese in a wide brimmed hat looks toward the camera with a woman out of the focus in the foreground

props.synopsis: Whichever party wins government at the upcoming federal election, the heightened focus on the Northern Territory in the lead-up is welcome proof its challenging issues aren’t just being swept under the rug.

title.children: Albanese and Dutton promise big for the NT, with one major caveat

image.altText: An image of dark clouds and intense rain falling on the landscape

props.synopsis: The long-awaited monsoon looks to officially kick in this weekend over northern Australia, helping to break up severe heatwave conditions plaguing much of the country. But the forecast rain is bad news for flood-ridden Queensland.

title.children: Heatwaves across the country set to ease as elusive monsoon rolls in

image.altText: Beach in Gaza

props.synopsis: After 15 months of war, children can still remember Gaza's beach side. But now, it has transformed into a vast landscape of destruction. Palestinians returning to their homes recall the better times.

title.children: Children once played by the ocean. Now Gaza's beaches are a 'sad' place

image.altText: Abbey Willcox, Laura Peel and Danielle Scott smile standing next to each other

props.synopsis: Australian skiers finish first, second, third and fourth at the FIS Freestyle World Cup event, the first time in history the nations' skiers have achieved the feat in aerials.

title.children: 'One to four is crazy': Aussies sweep podium in historic World Cup victory

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: close up of the joachim-ma stradivarius violin

props.synopsis: The Joachim-Ma Stradivarius is regarded as one of Stradivari's best works and was built during his Golden Period at the height of his craftsmanship.

title.children: 300-year-old Stradivarius violin fetches over $18 million at auction

image.altText: Palm trees stand in floodwaters.

props.synopsis: The risk of widespread heavy rainfall has reduced for flood-ravaged north Queensland, but there is still the potential for monsoonal bursts.

title.children: 'Dangerous' flash flooding risk continues for soaked north Queensland

image.altText: A chauffeur in a black suit opening the door of a black car.

props.synopsis: For years politicians have used their private travel paid for by the taxpayer in questionable ways — from chauffeuring pet pooches to a country home, to having petrol paid for while on holidays.

title.children: Chauffeuring dogs, paid petrol: Ministerial driver rules for state politicians

image.altText: Heavy machinery, including a truck and shovel, inside a gold mine.

props.synopsis: Western Australia's economy leads the nation, but it's done little to alleviate the state's crippling housing crisis.

title.children: WA's economy is the envy of the nation, so why is the housing crisis persisting?

image.altText: A building almost completely under floodwater.

props.synopsis: As Queensland faces further flooding, a review into last year's severe weather season has found damning issues in accessing emergency services and support.

title.children: Warning failures left Queensland disaster victims abandoned, report finds

image.altText: Three middle-aged men pictured in separate photos side by side

props.synopsis: The release of hostages and prisoners is a sign that the deal is moving forward, even as US and Israeli officials continue to call for the relocation of Gaza's population after the war.

title.children: Hamas names three more Israeli hostages to be freed as ceasefire deal holds

image.altText: An old beige coloured building with outside corridors going around it.

props.synopsis: Former asylum Willow Court joins locations such as a former concentration camp in Europe and an African slave house as one of 365 global "Sites of Conscience".

title.children: Australia's oldest hospital for mental illness finds global recognition

image.altText: A mother and daughter sit in front of their house

props.synopsis: There are barely any long-term rental properties available in the popular WA coastal town of Esperance. But can an abundance of holiday homes be blamed?

title.children: Airbnb was the 'lucrative' choice, but this family decided against it

image.altText: A woman with brown hair wearing a black jacket walks past TV cameras guided by a bald man in a black jacket

props.synopsis: The jury heard from Ms Kerr's friends, family and professional soccer teammates who spoke glowingly about her character, as the prosecution closed its case.

title.children: Sam Kerr is 'shy' and 'level-headed' off the pitch, friends tell racial harassment trial

image.altText: a graphic of a man being arrested with telegram logos flying across it

props.synopsis: In an Australian first, sanctions have been put on the online far-right extremist network Terrorgram. But if the US moves away from combating the problem under President Trump, could tackling emerging threats become harder?

title.children: No leaders, no uniforms but here's why Terrorgram is a global threat

image.altText: A man and woman cuddling in bed.

props.synopsis: Researchers say part of the reason why strangulation during sex is so common may be because many people mistakenly believe that, while risky, it can be made safe.

title.children: Young Australians have misconceptions about choking during sex

image.altText: young woman with dark hair wearing glasses

props.synopsis: More than 10 per cent of West Australians aged 18 to 30 aren't enrolled to vote, making up thousands of people across the state who are missing the opportunity to have a say.

title.children: 'I'm just confused': Why young people are not enrolling to vote

image.altText: A man in a white beekeeping suit kneels with a large yellow box in front of beehives.

props.synopsis: Australian beekeepers are looking overseas to find chemical-free solutions to manage the world's deadliest bee parasite.

title.children: Heat could help kill deadly bee parasite varroa mite

image.altText: A young girl lines up for a plate of food

props.synopsis: Students are trying new foods as more schools are getting free lunches, and teachers say it's benefiting not just their bellies.

title.children: This is what free school lunches look like, as Tasmania expands program

image.altText: A red dirt road amongst a dry cattle station with dying shrubs

props.synopsis: Residents in the hottest parts of Australia say the extreme weather is making it impossible to work outdoors safely during the day, as thirsty camels create an additional challenge for cattle stations.

title.children: Outback temperatures too hot for electronics as residents 'try to survive'

image.altText: The graphic includes three polaroid photos of Eric Mercy with big groups of First Nations children

props.synopsis: A surfing legend is being remembered for his "big heart" after he took his own life in the late 90s. But in this community, his story isn't the only one. With the power of their connection and the ocean, his children are fighting to change that.

title.children: The tragic death of a surfing hero led a community to take action
